Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I developed a plethora of knowledge about various topics in organic chemistry. I built upon the knowledge and skills I gained last semester, and I believe that I have become a more critical thinker and a more insightful chemist.
I learned many reactions and ways to synthesize organic compounds. My problem solving and critical thinking skills definitely increased.
Lots of reactions
I learned about spectroscopy methods, benzylic/allylic reactivity, aromatic compounds, carbonyls, and nitrates, as well as their roles in synthesis.

I learned how to consider chemical reactions, properties, processes, ect. through a variety of intersecting lenses. I have a much larger and greater appreciation for chemistry as a field and have a greater understanding for all natural sciences as a consequence.
I learned SO MUCH in this class. It was such a help for problem solving and scientific thinking, as well as just learning so much Chemistry.
Interpreting NMR, more reactions (alkynes, dienes, aromatic, carbonyl chemistry). More intuition for organic chemistry.
Problem solving skills related to organic chemistry.
Orgo. Elleman was actually helpful and we learned things pretty well and got things internalized!
Organic chemistry with nitrogen and carbonyls, transition metal chemistry, IR and NMR, building on orgo intuition from last semester, why we should study chemistry!
How to think about the way things react critically

Second semester orgo was where organic chemistry really got interesting. We learned about many named reactions that are very relevant to organic syntheses. We developed our intuition on the flow of electrons and how different organic compounds can interact.
Basics of organic chemistry
We expanded to learning transition metal chemistry, reactions with aromatic rings etc,
I learned new chemical reactions and basic organic chemistry concepts.
Critical thinking, chemistry knowledge
Reactions with ketones, carboxylic acid derivatives, enols and enolates, etc.
A continuation of the skills from last semester.
I gained the ability to think and learn as a scientists would and not by memorization.
I now know what organic chemistry is and have a great foundation of knowledge of reactions.
Taught me different ways of problem solving
Developed understanding of fundamentals of organic chemistry as well as potential applications of that knowledge.
A basic understanding of important organic chemistry concepts, mechanisms, and reactions.
I developed analytical skills necessary to work through problems. I also learned new lab techniques.
I developed chemical intuition and how to rely less on memorization.

many reactions and their mechanisms and the underlying chemistry behind why they happen; spectroscopic techniques
how to think critically and apply chemistry knowledge to new situations
organic chemistry from a theoretical perspective
I developed further understanding of organic chemistry (continuation from orgo 1).

I learned problem solving skills, lots and lots of reactions, and other topics in organic chemistry. One half of Organic Chemistry is memorization of the material and knowledge; the other half is applying that knowledge as if they are individual pieces to a larger puzzle. Synthesis and Mechanism reactions, for example, require both memorization as well as puzzle-like application of what was memorized.
I learned a lot about organic chemistry. This semester focuses a lot on aromatic and carbonyl chemistry. It also covers a bit in organometallic and analytical methods like IR and NMR.
Started with alkyne chemistry and moved into reaaal heavy duty synthesis by the end.

Continuation of synthesis, interpretation of NMR and IR data, understanding of diene, aromatic, alkynes, transition metals, carbonyl and amine compound reactivity. Learned to further develop pathways and reagents required to synthesize particular compounds.

I learned more organic chemistry reactions, how to be more proficient in drawing reaction mechanisms, and how to predict reaction mechanisms.  This course really was a continuation of Orgo 1, and prior knowledge of Orgo 1 was necessary.
Furthering of interesting reactions
My analytical and reasoning skills improved by taking this course.
I built on my knowledge of organic chemistry principles and reactions from Organic Chemistry 1
The most valuable aspect of this course is the development of critical thinking that can be applied to anything else.
I furthered my understanding of organic chemistry, especially in biological contexts.
I learned much about organic chemistry and realized my passion did not lie in molecules

Strengths: The lectures were very helpful and engaging! Sections were also helpful because the TFs would go over topics from lectures and also provide challenging problems for us to solve. Problem sets were manageable and they helped me learn the topics for each week.

Weaknesses: It would be better if the lectures covered material relevant to the problem set due that week, instead of covering material from the following chapter. I tend to learn better from a lecture if I read the material in the textbook beforehand, but because I am completing the problem set for the previous chapter I find it hard to also read the following chapter in preparation for lectures.

A strength of this course is the enthusiasm of the professors. The class covers a lot of material and is definitely challenging, but the professors, TAs, and peer tutors are all very helpful and supportive.
The course moved very quickly hard to keep up

Strengths:
-Instructors care genuinely about the subject matter and students
-Practice exams before midterms were very similar to the real exams, good preparation
-Easy to see real-life significance of subject matter
Weaknesses:
-A generally difficult subject
-Would have been better taught as a seminar
-Alternatively, this course would have been perfect as an advanced organic chemistry course, but it was a bit too much for both an introduction and for all the advanced material we covered

The course was incredibly interesting in terms of subject matter and the professors were absolutely delightful. The TAs were also very friendly and helpful and made a subject that is supposed to be terrible and hard actually pretty fun. Lectures always consisted of theory and then the practice applications of those concepts (like the development of historically relevant drugs) which made everything we learned feel very meaningful. I will miss this class dearly.

Strengths--Professors Ellman and Scott, DIONDRA (best TF I've ever had; so amazing), the psets are really helpful to stay on track, lecture is incredibly helpful and I could never imagine missing

Weaknesses--it is a LOT of work, and I definitely spent by far the most time on this class as compared to others. The exams are very difficult

I think that overall, this is a very good course. I like that the problem sets are graded for completion, and the midterms and final really challenge you and make you think beyond what was covered in class. I felt as if some topics were covered more slowly, and others were rushed through, so I wish that we spent more time on difficult chapters (such as the carboxylic acid derivative chapter), and less time on alkynes and other topics at the beginning of the semester. The third midterm covered way more material than the first two combined, so I think that it should be more even.

The way first-year orgo is taught is incredible. Unlike traditional organic chemistry classes that focus on nomenclature and memorization, this class is entirely conceptual; the focus is on mechanisms and why things happen. The tests are difficult but interesting, much like the class itself  its worth it, especially to be taught by such inspiring professors.
Really enjoyed the course

Strengths: Learning modern and relevant pathways of organic synthesis; knowledgeable professors and TAs
Weaknesses: Some separation between what we are tested on and the textbook material

The first four weeks of the course were very slow-paced, and the last four weeks incredibly rushed. There should jot be a large focus on NMR theory and other spectroscopic theory, as it is covered un the lab section.  The course was very good at preparing me to think about mechanisms for various systems.

Strengths are that it is an important course that everyone should take.
Weaknesses include highly varied difficulty of tests between instructors.

The course was very strong in its ability to connect abstract concepts from one chapter through the next, creating a continuous story of Chemistry. As opposed to separate sections, this made the course feel like an experience.
It's easy to get lost and stay lost in this class and the exams are significantly harder than PSET qs.

The professors are very good at teaching.

Having two professors is confusing since the two professors have different teaching and lecturing styles.

Strengths: Umm
Weaknesses: 2 professors makes it harder to maintain a consistent learning/teaching style, very few online/review resources

Strength: professor is very knowledgable and engaging, class is well-run
Weakness: more review before midterms would be nice, although it is quite satisfactory currently

The course is designed to be very intensive and conducive to exploration. Both professors and TAs have unparalleled commitment to studying and teaching chemistry. The gap between what is taught and what is tested is unpredictable, which is probably one of the only yet prime concerns of all students in the course.
The strengths are the professors Ability to give us students the curiosity they have.

I did not feel like the problem sets were very helpful. The first few questions were relevant, but the rest usually involved an unmanageable level of difficulty that was not relevant to the material covered in class. The TF's and peer tutors were a big strength.
Professor  Ellman was an incredible teacher and I always enjoyed going to his class. He made the course very manageable and he understood our skills sets very well.
There were a lot of resources to learn the material. Some of the lectures could have been clearer.

I felt as though the lectures could have been more organized. Professor Ellman did a great job of putting titles on the chalkboard and doing a short review at the beginning of the class, and I wish that style was carried throughout the semester.
The only improvement I would make is make homeworks have problems more like on the tests if possible.

Strengths: interesting and challenging content; fast-paced; lots of support from TAs
Weaknesses: lectures sometimes too fast and hard to follow; problem sets and class content did not always align
Improved by testing on things we learned - i.e. a more class focused test, also doing more practice problems that resemble those on the test so we are better prepared
This is an amazing course!!

All the TAs and Professors want you to learn and succeed in this class. I felt very supported in Chem 175, and I felt that I had all the resources available for me to succeed. TA sessions were especially helpful, as they were organized and correlated closely with the lectures from that week. Lectures were a little difficult to keep up with, as they were fast-paced and surveyed a lot of information from the textbook. I feel the lectures could be a little bit more organized.
It covers a lot in a short amount of times but I feel the class sometimes goes too in depth on less important topics which arent tested and glosses over more core topics which are tested over.

Strengths: This class gives more to chew on than the first semester so it doesn't feel so tedious. Also, now that you know all the basics, it feels more practical. the HUGE negative of this class was the pacing. Going up to the middle of the term, the first two exams were pretty easily and only had a few chapters worth of material, which was in line with past exams in orgo I. However, because the second semester is pretty packed, this meant that the thirs and final midterm exam covered about 5 chapters worth of material--about 400 pages of the textbook. Everything from phenols to transition metal catalysts to EVERYTHING about carbonyl chemistry (it's a LOT). I feel like some of that stuff at the end could have been distributed better to make the third midterm a little less daunting

Strengths: subject was very interesting and highly applicable, enjoyed Prof Miller's applications of organic chemistry to drug development and medicine (penicillin, AIDS crisis), and loved that class was challenging and required students to build an intuition based on a growing library of reactions and mechanisms; Weaknesses: going through practice problems in class would have been helpful especially regarding synthesis style questions or NMR/IR interpretation, mechanisms were often drawn very quickly so that if you did not keep up in class you would have to copy the board without thinking through what was going on

The homework was nice and sweet (most times), but I think I would have benefited more from something like the worksheets the TAs gave out in section. I had to mostly relearn everything at TA sections, learn everything else outside of class using Khan Academy, and I didn't feel like I understood the material completely until after classes were over when I was studying for the final. Also, I know the curriculum stuck with the textbook, but the textbook itself doesn't teach the content in a way that was logical, so I would recommend using another organic chemistry textbook. The lab and class content did not line up at all, which made learning difficult. Finally, there was too much material on the last midterm and not enough on the first two, so I think spreading it out would be helpful for students.
Hard to figure out whats necessary and how to organize information
The TA's were very helpful!
The pace seemed to fast at times and too slow at others

I would recommend this course to another student, but I would warn them that it is a very challenging course. The lectures are very well-thought-out and the professor and TFs are always willing to answer any questions or provide help outside of class, but it is very easy to get behind on work because lectures are very fast-paced and material gets covered very quickly.
Yes I would recommend this course to another student because although it was definitely a challenge, the professors, TAs, and peer tutors were very supportive and helpful and I learned a lot.
No. Do not take this class unless you are required to. While it's not the worst course in the world, it's not some silly elective you can get a credit from.
No it was too hard and annoying but a requirement for many things
This is an interesting, but not easy, class. I recommend this course to students considering a chemistry/chemical engineering/bio major, but it can be somewhat overwhelming otherwise.
Yes! Many people think that orgo is terrible but don't knock it 'til you try it! The instructors (professors and TAs) make this class great.
Yes! Especially if you're premed and you have to take it, but I actually ended up really enjoying it much more than I thought I would.

I would absolutely recommend this course! If you are deciding between gen chem and orgo, TAKE THIS CLASS! The professor(s) are amazing, and it's really nice to be in a class full of first-years. I have learned so much, and this has probably been one of my favorite classes so far.
Only if it's required.

If youve placed into first-year orgo and youre not sure whether youre ready to take it, take it. Forget all of the horror stories youve heard about orgo and naming gross compounds. This class is taught differently by inspiring professors who want you to succeed. Even if youre somewhat shaky on your gen chem, almost all of the concepts are new with everybody learning them for the first time. The bonds you learn about are just as important as the bonds you make with your classmates in such a small lecture course. Second semester builds on the concepts of first semester in an interesting way (more complicated, more biochem, transition metals too) that feels natural. Second semester is also easier than first semester, whether thats because you get used to the course structure or your orgo intuition is growing.

Yes. Take this course if you any of the following: pre-med, interested in a chemistry-related major, or STEM enthusiast. The best part of First-Year Orgo is that you meet many first years that share your interests.
it's required for the chem major, so there's not much choice about it. if you were to take chemistry for fun, gen chem ought to cover the basics.

I would without a heartbeat recommend Organic Chemistry for First Year Students II to other students.  It was such a great course, taught by a great professor, that challenged me academically and always left more to be learned, questioned, and considered.
The instructor genuinely cares about the students learning and he is a genuinely interesting lecturer. I just think organic chemistry itself is difficult to grasp.
I would recommend this course to another student because its interesting how we can synthesize compounds with the reactions learned.
Probably not, unless they are very STEM-oriented and have taken organic chemistry in high school
Yes, it's definitely worth it for acceleration and the class has a lot of avenues for help. Great class but a lot had to do with Professor Ellman and Professor Miller.
Yes, probably to those who feel at least comfortable with general concepts of chemistry and the first semester.
I would recommend this course to any student wishing to pursue a career in science.
Yes if they are interested in chemistry at all and especially like to understand biochemical reactions.
Yes, if you need it for a major or pre-med.
I would recommend to first years who want to take Organic Chemistry (over the other organic chemistry course) because the professors are more understanding of the college transition.
I would recommend only if required. If you are a first year who needs organic chemistry and can take it as a first year student, take it.
Depends on youre willingness to learn from failures.
Yes, if you are interested in chemistry.

I would recommend this course to another student, but advise them that it is a lot of work each week and to not opt to take it concurrently with other strenuous courses. I would also suggest adding the "Organic Chemistry as A Second Language" book to the course description as a recommended material. Many of us found that helpful.
Definitely. It is 100% worth it to get organic chemistry out of the way in your first year if you will have to take it eventually.
Yes, you will learn so much and develop problem solving skills.

honestly just take the regular orgo class, the only thing this one is good for is meeting people in your year in STEM but you're better off taking a class that is better suited to the upper classes you'll take based on orgo (biochem, etc.)
I would definitely recommend this course! The hard work paid off!

I would recommend this class to incoming first-years. A lot of students drop out from 174, and while 175 is much more intellectually challenging that first semester, it is more or less the same feel. If you are beginning to realize that you are no longer interested in STEM, however, I would advise maybe taking other science classes instead. I took this in hopes of being premed; I am no longer premed, but I still believed I got a lot out of this class.

Id take it if you are doing anything Med, Bio or Chem related even if its not required. Its hard and difficult but it will help you regardless. If you are taking a science for fun, Id spare your sanity and time by not taking this class.

Yeah, but I am genuinely interesting in chemistry. If you are a premed, you have to take this course, and if you are a person who wants to get deeper into chemistry, this course won't kill you. But this is important--if you are a first-year who took chemistry in highschool and just sort of think "well this is what I'm supposed to do next" DO NOT DO IT. This class is way too hard and way too much time to just sort of be going through the motions. Think about what genuinely interests you and go from there.

Yes! organic chemistry is fascinating to learn even if it can be challenging. the second half of this course completes your knowledge of mechanisms and reactions regarding all sorts of functional groups so that by the end of it you'll find yourself equipped to work in an organic lab for instance and understand almost everything that is going on regarding the theory and mechanisms. Prof. Ellman and Miller teach very well and TAs were very helpful to go to for additional assistance. people will warn you about how terrible orgo is or how it's the class that fails all premeds but don't fear - it isn't actually bad if you put effort in to understand the "whys" and not just the "whats"

I would recommend this course to another student because it's an interesting subject! However, if the course continued to be taught in this way, I don't think it would be worth it. This class literally made me cry because I felt like I wasn't understanding the material. I know at other universities they actually cover important fundamental material and students learn well, but I don't think this is what students here get, and I feel like it would be more worth taking this course elsewhere.
Sure
I would recommend this course because taking first year organic chemistry allows students to skip general chemistry.
Definitely. I found the course material and professors engaging.
Only if you are pre-med or chemistry major
